channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Is This the NSA Leaker’s Special Travel Document?
item.description: The Spanish-language television network Univision has obtained what appears to be a copy of the special travel document granted to Edward Snowden by Ecuador to replace his cancelled American passport.
item.dc:creator: By RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Europe Agrees on New Banking Rules
item.description: European Union finance ministers reached a plan that laid out the order in which shareholders, creditors and others would cover losses suffered when banks collapse.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: France's finance minister, Pierre Moscovici, on Tuesday in Paris. In Brussels, he hailed the deal and the solidarity it fosters.

item.title: Court Hears Arguments on Whaling by Japan
item.description: Hearings began at The Hague into an Australian suit charging Japan with unlawful practices and with using so-called research as a front for commercial whaling.
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS
item.media:credit: Australian Customs Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by Australia in 2008 shows a whale being dragged by a Japanese ship in Antarctic waters.

item.title: Rare Visit Underscores Tangles in Obama’s Ties to Africa
item.description: President Obama’s aspirations for changing Africa have been strained by mounting security threats, spotty human rights records and by his notable absence from the continent where his father was born.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR, NICHOLAS KULISH and LYDIA POLGREEN
item.media:description: Posters of President Obama and Macky Sall, the president of Senegal, filled a wall in Dakar before Mr. Obama’s arrival on Wednesday, the start of a weeklong trip to Africa.

item.title: The Lede: A Conversation With Assad (No, Not That One)
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has antagonized many people, including some members of his own extended family. One, a cousin who has long lived in Western exile, is making the rounds in the United States.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Group Belatedly Claims Attack in Greece
item.description: The Group of Popular Rebels claimed responsibility on Wednesday for an attack in January saying it was protesting the government’s continuing austerity drive.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Pope Francis Appoints Panel to Watch Bank
item.description: The committee is authorized to gather documents, data and information about the bank with the “prompt collaboration” of the bank’s staff and that of other Vatican departments.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Watchdog Group to Be Closed in Russia
item.description: Golos gained prominence for identifying voter fraud during parliamentary elections in 2011 and is facing a temporary suspension.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Former Governor Arrested in Mexico
item.description: Andrés Granier of Tabasco State, was taken into custody on Tuesday on charges of embezzling millions of dollars in public funds.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: Cairo Journal: Anger at Egypt’s Leaders Intensifies in Gas Lines
item.description: Long gas lines are among a confluence of crises feeding discontent among Egyptians as plans for protests this weekend stir fears of violence and instability.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptians waited for hours in gas lines on Wednesday in Dokki, a Cairo neighborhood.

item.title: In Canada, Pipeline Remarks Stir Analysis
item.description: President Obama, in Canada, says the Keystone XL pipeline would be built only if carbon pollution would not increase.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: New Species of Bird Is Found in an Unlikely Location in Cambodia
item.description: Roughly the same size as a wren, with white cheeks and a cinnamon cap, the Cambodian tailorbird’s primary habitat is in the outskirts of the Cambodian capital.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Ashish John/Wildlife Conservation Society, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Cambodian tailorbird was found near Phnom Penh.

item.title: Counterfeit Food More Widespread Than Suspected
item.description: Investigators have uncovered thousands of schemes involving counterfeit or adulterated food, some on an industrial scale and in developed countries.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: Liters of fake vodka were distilled and pumped into genuine Glen's Vodka bottles, and packed with forged labels and duty stamps.

item.title: News Analysis: Brussels Official, Criticizing France, Turns Up Heat on a Tense Relationship
item.description: José Manuel Barroso, the European Commission president, said French criticism of globalization harmed cultural diversity, angering both the left and the right in France.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: José Manuel Barroso, the European Commission president, said French criticism of globalization harmed cultural diversity.

item.title: Egypt’s Leader, Morsi, Admits Mistakes
item.description: In a televised speech ahead of planned weekend demonstrations by his opponents, President Mohamed Morsi pledged to introduce “radical and quick” reforms.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: As World Awaits News on Mandela, Tensions Rise Over Media Swarm
item.description: A central dilemma for the government is how to reconcile the voracious, concern-driven appetite for news of Nelson Mandela’s health with the deep sensitivities of South Africans for whom he is much more than a simple leader.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Children gathered outside the hospital in Pretoria where Nelson Mandela is receiving care.

item.title: Australian Prime Minister Is Ousted by Party Rival
item.description: Standing for a vote, Prime Minister Julia Gillard lost to the man she toppled in a 2010 Labor Party coup.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:description: Prime Minister Julia Gillard of Australia announced her resignation after losing a leadership vote to Kevin Rudd on Wednesday in Canberra.

item.title: A Legal Defeat for Anne Frank House
item.description: A district court in Amsterdam has ordered the Anne Frank House to return a collection of archives to the Frank family foundation.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: The diary of Anne Frank at the Frank House in Amsterdam, which must give up archives.

item.title: Visions of a Greener Pipeline
item.description: The changes are one part of an industrywide campaign aimed at winning the Obama administration’s approval for a pipeline extension.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Austerity Remains Key to Britain’s Economic Plan
item.description: George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, outlined a continuing policy of austerity for Britain with welfare and public-spending restraint the key to his party’s policies.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Under Snowden Screen Name, 2009 Post Berated Leaks
item.description: The Web site Ars Technica published logs of online chats in which Edward J. Snowden was believed to have participated, telling a friend that leakers “should be shot.”
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Cuomo and Canada Have Peace Bridge Deal
item.description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and Canadian officials announced an agreement that laid out a plan to improve the American side of the bridge that connects Buffalo to Fort Erie in Canada.
item.category: Buffalo and Fort Erie Public Bridge Authority
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: Brendan Bannon for The New York Times
item.media:description: An agreement announced in Buffalo on Wednesday laid out a plan to improve the American side of the Peace Bridge.

item.title: Ecuador Hints at Slow Process on Snowden Asylum
item.description: The tiny South American nation signaled it may take its time with Edward J. Snowden’s application, raising the possibility that he could spend weeks in legal limbo.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Passengers in the transit zone of Moscow's Sheremetyevo International Airport on Wednesday.

item.title: Copter Crash Kills 19 as Flood Rescue Efforts Strain Indian Air Force
item.description: Airlifts have evacuated 12,000, but pilots say the mountains, winds and lack of landing pads are testing their will and courage.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Wood for a mass cremation was unloaded Tuesday in Uttarakhand State for air transport to Kedarnath, a pilgrimage destination submerged by flooding.

item.title: DNA Buried 7,000 Centuries Is Retrieved
item.description: The genome is 10 times as old as any retrieved so far, and scientists now say that DNA should be recoverable from animals that lived a million years ago.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS WADE
item.media:description: Researchers have recovered an ancient genome from a 700,000-year-old horse fossil in Canada. They are also analyzing the genomes of many members of the horse evolutionary tree, including the Przewalski horse, a species thought to represent the last living wild horse population.
